questions.text:
A 66-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician because of a severely painful right ear with discharge for 10 days. The ear pain was acute in onset and is constant. She has been using over-the-counter eardrops but her symptoms have continued to worsen. Her only medication is insulin, which she uses inconsistently. Her temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 108/min, and blood pressure is 130/90 mm Hg. Examination of the right ear shows a swollen pinna and lobule and malodorous purulent discharge; the ear is tender to touch. Posterior auricular lymphadenopathy is present. There is mild hearing loss of the right ear. Otoscopic examination shows a swollen ear canal with granulation tissue. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
13.3 g/dL


Hemoglobin A1c

12.2%


Leukocyte count
18,300/mm3



 Segmented neutrophils
76%


 Eosinophils
1%


 Lymphocytes
20%


 Monocytes
3%


Serum



 Glucose
212 mg/dL


 Creatinine
1.7 mg/dL


A CT scan of the head shows severe thickening and enhancing of the soft tissue of the external auditory canal with patchy destruction of the temporal bone. Culture results of the ear drainage are pending. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Metronidazole is a drug with both antibacterial and antiprotozoal activity, which offers coverage against anaerobic bacteria. Although anaerobes may cause chronic suppurative otitis media, they are not involved in malignant otitis externa. While chronic suppurative otitis media may also manifest with ear discharge and hearing loss, this condition does not manifest with ear pain or swelling of the external auditory canal.
Image Description:

Otoscopic image of the middle ear

The tympanic membrane is completely perforated and the tympanic cavity can be seen. The mucous membrane of the tympanic cavity is edematous and covered by clear secretions.

These findings are diagnostic of chronic suppurative otitis media, which can develop from acute otitis media with tympanic membrane perforation.

B) INCORRECT:

Amoxicillin-clavulanate is used as first-line therapy for acute otitis media (AOM) because of its efficacy against Streptococcus pneumoniae, the main cause of AOM. While AOM can also manifest with acute onset of ear pain, fever, and mastoiditis, this patient lacks a red and bulging tympanic membrane. In addition, AOM typically affects infants and young children between 6–24 months of age. Malignant otitis externa is most commonly caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, for which amoxicillin-clavulanate is not effective.

C) INCORRECT:

Clarithromycin is a macrolide antibiotic that is, e.g., used to treat acute otitis media (AOM) in patients with severe allergies to penicillin. While AOM may also manifest with acute onset of ear pain, fever, and mastoiditis, this patient, however, lacks a red and bulging tympanic membrane. Also, a swollen ear canal with granulation tissue suggests an external ear infection and AOM is much more common in infants and young children between 6–24 months of age.
Image Description:

Otoscopic image of the tympanic membrane

There is bulging and erythema of the tympanic membrane, which appears dull and thickened. The light reflex is visible in the posterior upper quadrant (should normally appear in the anterior lower quadrant) and appears widened and heterogeneous due to bulging of the membrane.

D) INCORRECT:

Clotrimazole eardrops are recommended for the treatment of fungal otitis externa, which may also manifest with ear pain, scaling, discharge, and mild hearing impairment, and is a common complication in patients with diabetes due to immunodeficiency. However, the condition is mainly characterized by excessive ear itching, which this patient lacks. Moreover, findings such as fungal filaments and spores (which would resemble mold on spoiled food) are usually seen upon otoscopy.
Image Description:

Otoscopy of the left ear

The external auditory canal and the tympanic membrane show multiple small white to yellowish appearance of fungal debris and fruiting bodies. They are partly confluent and involve the entire visible area of the auditory canal. Hyphae and fungal spores are visible at the top and bottom of the meatus.

These findings are usually caused by Aspergillus spp. or Candida spp. and are typical for otitis externa mycotica.

E) INCORRECT:

Eardrops containing ciprofloxacin and hydrocortisone have potent activity against Pseudomonas aeruginosa and are the first-line treatment for uncomplicated otitis externa. In this patient, however, the infection has already spread to the mastoid bone, indicating a severe and complicated course that would not be treated adequately with topical drugs.
Image Description:

There is swelling and mild erythema of the external auditory canal and auricle. Purulent discharge from the external auditory canal is visible. The auditory canal appears to be obstructed.

These findings are consistent with otitis externa.

F) CORRECT:

The initial empiric therapy for malignant otitis externa should include high-dose IV ciprofloxacin, which is usually combined with another antipseudomonal agent from a different class (e.g., cefepime, ceftazidime, or piperacillin/tazobactam). Malignant otitis externa most frequently occurs in older patients with poorly controlled diabetes or individuals with immunosuppression. Complications include facial nerve palsy and osteomyelitis of the skull base, possibly leading to extradural abscesses, cerebral venous sinus thrombosis, and paralysis of other cranial nerves. Surgical debridement is indicated for abscess drainage and removal of bony sequestrum.

G) INCORRECT:

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) is the pharmacotherapy of choice for cutaneous nocardiosis, which typically occurs in older or immunocompromised patients (e.g., individuals with diabetes). Cutaneous nocardiosis may affect the facial skin and manifests with signs of cellulitis (pain, swelling, erythema, warmth), ulceration, and local lymphadenopathy. However, nocardiosis is a rare infection that typically affects the lungs (pulmonary nocardiosis). Malignant otitis externa is most commonly caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, for which TMP-SMX is not effective.
questions.hint: Severe ear pain, otorrhea, otoscopic findings of granulation tissue, and ear canal edema as well as evidence of bone destruction on CT scan suggest malignant otitis externa, which is most commonly caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

questions.text: A 64-year-old homeless man comes to the emergency department with right ear pain and difficulty hearing for 2 weeks. Over the last 5 days, he has also noticed discharge from his right ear. He does not recall the last time he saw a physician. His temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 113/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 153/92 mm Hg. He appears dirty and is malodorous. Physical examination shows mild facial asymmetry with the right corner of his mouth lagging behind the left when the patient smiles. He experiences severe ear pain when the right auricle is pulled superiorly. On otoscopic examination, there is granulation tissue at the transition between the cartilaginous and the osseous part of the ear canal. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Malignant epithelial growth of the external auditory canal

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although malignant epithelial growth (e.g., squamous cell carcinoma) of the external auditory canal that has extended into the temporal bone can manifest with ear pain, this is a rare location for malignancy. Also, this patient's signs of systemic infection (fever and tachycardia), and the presence of granulation tissue in the ear canal suggest an infectious, not malignant, etiology.

B) INCORRECT:

Condylar degeneration (e.g., in temporomandibular joint disorder) can manifest with ear pain. However, this patient's findings suggest osteomyelitis of the skull (severe pain with ear movement and facial nerve palsy) that has progressed to systemic infection (fever and tachycardia). These findings, in addition to necrotizing granulation tissue in the ear canal, are inconsistent with condylar degeneration, as the condition is a noninfectious process that is localized to the temporomandibular joint itself.

C) INCORRECT:

Opacified mastoid air cells can be found in patients with acute or chronic infections of the sinus or middle ear. Since the middle ear communicates with the mastoid process, otitis media can result in opacification of these air cells. However, this patient likely has an infection of the external ear, which does not communicate directly with the mastoid process and is therefore not commonly associated with opacified mastoid air cells. The mastoid can be affected if the infection spreads from the temporal bone to adjacent bones, but a different finding is much more likely in malignant otitis externa.
Image Description:

Left retroauricular region of a child

There is pronounced erythema and swelling, with ventral protrusion of the pinna as a result of swelling. The features are typical of mastoiditis, which can occur as a complication of otitis media.

D) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common bacterial cause of acute otitis media. Acute otitis media typically manifests with ear pain and fever, but more serious complications, such as osteomyelitis of the skull and cranial nerve palsies, are rare. Otoscopy in acute otitis media shows bulging of the tympanic membrane, not granulation tissue in the canal. Also, acute otitis media most commonly affects young children. This patient has malignant otitis externa, which is most commonly caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

E) CORRECT:

Older patients with diabetes (which manifests with an elevated HbA1c) are at the greatest risk for developing malignant otitis externa. The specific connection between diabetes mellitus and malignant otitis externa is not fully understood, but may be related to increased pH in diabetic cerumen. Given the strong association between the two conditions, this patient most likely has diabetes. Also, the patient's lack of primary care access puts him at increased risk for the development of chronic diseases, like diabetes mellitus, and their complications.

Malignant otitis externa is a severe infection with significant mortality that is most commonly caused by P. aeruginosa. This patient should undergo imaging studies (CT scan and/or MRI) to identify bone destruction and to determine the extent of intracranial involvement. Following blood cultures, intravenous antibiotic therapy (preferably with two antipseudomonal agents) should be initiated. Surgical debridement is indicated only for abscess drainage and removal of bony sequestrum.
Image Description:

There is swelling and mild erythema of the external auditory canal and auricle. Purulent discharge from the external auditory canal is visible. The auditory canal appears to be obstructed.

These findings are consistent with otitis externa.
questions.hint: Ear pain, otorrhea, hearing loss, and granulation tissue in the external auditory canal are consistent with malignant otitis externa, which has most likely progressed to osteomyelitis of the temporal bone with systemic infection (indicated by fever, tachycardia, and facial nerve palsy).

questions.text: A 72-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with painful discharge from his right ear with difficulty hearing for 3 days. His temperature is 39.5°C (103.1°F) and pulse is 120/min. Physical examination shows mild facial asymmetry with the right corner of his mouth lagging behind the left when the patient smiles. There is severe ear pain when the right auricle is pulled superiorly. Otoscopic examination shows granulation tissue at the transition between the cartilaginous and the osseous part of the ear canal. Which of the following is most likely associated with this patient's condition?

choices.text: Invasive tumor of external auditory canal

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although an invasive tumor (e.g., squamous cell carcinoma) of the external auditory canal that has extended into the temporal bone could present with ear pain, this is a rare location for malignancy. Also, this patient's signs of severe systemic infection (fever and tachycardia), and the presence of granulation tissue in the ear canal suggest an acutely infectious, not malignant, etiology.

B) INCORRECT:

Acutely decreased intracranial perfusion can present with cranial nerve VII (CN VII) palsy, in the setting of acute ischemic stroke. However, other signs of acute stroke that commonly occur with unilateral facial nerve palsy, including one-sided weakness of the extremities, are absent in this patient. Furthermore, stroke cannot explain the painful ear discharge with signs of systemic infection.

C) CORRECT:

There is a strong association between diabetes mellitus and the development of malignant otitis externa, which is most commonly caused by an infection with Pseudomonas aeruginosa. The specific connection between diabetes mellitus and malignant otitis externa is not fully understood but may be related to increased pH in diabetic cerumen. Elderly diabetic patients are especially at risk for this potentially fatal condition. Following blood cultures, empiric systemic antibiotic therapy should be initiated and cranial imaging performed.

D) INCORRECT:

Pus-filled mastoid air cells is a sign of mastoiditis, which can be a complication after acute or chronic infections of the sinus or middle ear. Since the middle ear communicates with the mastoid process, otitis media can result in opacification of the mastoid's air cells on imaging. However, this patient likely has an infection of the external ear, which does not communicate directly with the mastoid process and is therefore not commonly associated with opacified mastoid air cells. The mastoid can be affected if the infection spreads from the temporal bone to adjacent bones, but a different finding is much more likely in malignant otitis external.

E) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common bacterial causes of acute otitis media. AOM typically presents with ear pain and fever, but more serious complications, like osteomyelitis of the skull and cranial nerve palsies, are rare. Otoscopy in AOM shows bulging of the tympanic membrane, not granulation tissue in the canal. Also, AOM most commonly affects young children. This patient is more likely to have an infection with Pseudomonas aeruginosa which is responsible for more than 95% of malignant external otitis cases.
questions.hint: This patient has a history and physical exam findings consistent with malignant otitis externa given his severe ear pain, vital sign abnormalities (i.e., high fever, tachycardia), facial droop (indicating progression to osteomyelitis of the temporal bone with associated CN VII palsy), and the presence of granulation tissue in the ear canal.

questions.text:
A 75-year-old man with a history of gout, type 2 diabetes, and hypothyroidism reports a 2-week history of severe pain and drainage in his left ear. He completed a 7-day course of amoxicillin-clavulanate several days ago but has persistent symptoms.
His temperature is 38°C, his heart rate is 90 beats per minute, and his blood pressure is 145/90 mm Hg. The external canal of his left ear is exquisitely tender and erythematous, and there is notable purulent discharge. The tympanic membrane appears normal. He has a subtle left-sided facial droop.
Culture of this patient's ear discharge is most likely to reveal which one of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Haemophilus influenzae and Streptococcus pneumoniae are both common causes of otitis media, particularly in children.

B) INCORRECT:

Although cases of malignant external otitis caused by Aspergillus fumigatus and Candida species (including Candida glabrata) have been reported, P. aeruginosa is by far the most common organism recovered from culture.

C) INCORRECT:

Although cases of malignant external otitis caused by Aspergillus fumigatus and Candida species (including Candida glabrata) have been reported, P. aeruginosa is by far the most common organism recovered from culture.

D) CORRECT:

Malignant external otitis is a necrotizing infection of the external auditory canal and surrounding tissues. Typically seen in older patients with type 2 diabetes or in immunocompromised individuals, malignant external otitis may manifest with severe otalgia out of proportion to the visible findings, otorrhea, and cranial-nerve palsies. The organism most commonly recovered on culture from patients with malignant external otitis is Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Malignant external otitis can be a life-threatening infection and has a high mortality rate. The mainstay of therapy is systemic antibiotics with antipseudomonal activity. Left untreated, malignant external otitis can develop into severe osteomyelitis of the temporal bone and invade cranial nerves, local tissue, and blood vessels.

Key learning point: The organism most commonly recovered on culture from patients with malignant external otitis is Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

E) INCORRECT:

Haemophilus influenzae and Streptococcus pneumoniae are both common causes of otitis media, particularly in children.

questions.text: A 66-year-old woman with poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the office because of a severely painful right ear with discharge for 10 days. Her temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F). Examination of the right ear shows a swollen pinna and lobule and malodorous purulent discharge; the ear is tender to touch. Posterior auricular lymphadenopathy is present. There is mild hearing loss in the right ear. Otoscopic examination shows a swollen ear canal with granulation tissue. A CT scan of the head shows severe thickening and enhancing of the soft tissue of the external auditory canal with patchy destruction of the temporal bone. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?

A) INCORRECT:

Amoxicillin-clavulanate is used as first-line therapy for acute otitis media (AOM) because of its efficacy against Streptococcus pneumoniae, the main cause of AOM. Also, a swollen ear canal with granulation tissue suggests an external ear infection and AOM is much more common in infants and young children between 6–24 months of age.

Clotrimazole eardrops are recommended for the treatment of fungal otitis externa, which may also manifest with ear pain, scaling, discharge, and mild hearing impairment, and is a common complication in patients with diabetes due to immunodeficiency. Otoscopy of the left ear

In this patient, however, the infection has already spread to the mastoid bone, indicating a severe and complicated course that would not be treated adequately with topical drugs.

There is swelling and mild erythema of the external auditory canal and auricle. Purulent discharge from the external auditory canal is visible. The auditory canal appears to be obstructed.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes presents with a 10-day history of left ear pain that awakens her at night. She reports difficulty chewing due to jaw pain. Physical examination shows an erythematous, edematous external auditory canal with purulent drainage and granulation tissue visible at the cartilage-bone junction. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), and WBC count is 8,500/μL. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Order blood cultures and begin IV vancomycin
Obtain CT head with IV contrast and consult otolaryngology
Discharge with oral analgesics and warm compresses
Perform ear canal irrigation and prescribe topical antibiotics
Start oral ciprofloxacin and schedule follow-up in 48 hours

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vancomycin is not the appropriate empiric choice for malignant otitis externa. Two antipseudomonal agents from different classes (e.g., ciprofloxacin plus either ceftazidime or piperacillin/tazobactam) are preferred. Furthermore, imaging studies are needed before initiating therapy.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- The clinical presentation of severe ear pain that is worse at night, jaw pain with chewing, granulation tissue at the cartilage-bone junction, and diabetes (a risk factor) strongly suggests malignant otitis externa. CT head with IV contrast is the preferred initial imaging study to evaluate for bone erosion and soft tissue involvement. Urgent otolaryngology consultation is needed because this condition typically requires hospitalization and prolonged IV antibiotic therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Conservative management is inappropriate for suspected malignant otitis externa. This condition requires emergency evaluation and, typically, hospitalization for IV antibiotics to prevent serious complications such as osteomyelitis and cranial nerve palsies.

D) INCORRECT:

Topical antibiotics may be considered as adjunctive therapy but are inadequate as primary treatment for malignant otitis externa.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral antibiotics alone are insufficient for malignant otitis externa. This condition requires systemic IV therapy with dual antipseudomonal agents, along with immediate imaging and specialist consultation to prevent serious complications.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman with diabetes presents with severe ear pain and otorrhea. CT head with contrast shows temporal bone erosion consistent with malignant otitis externa. Blood cultures are pending. Gram stain of ear drainage shows gram-negative rods. Which initial antibiotic regimen is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Single-agent therapy with ciprofloxacin is inadequate for malignant otitis externa.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- Malignant otitis externa requires initial empiric therapy with two antipseudomonal agents from different classes. Ciprofloxacin (fluoroquinolone) combined with ceftazidime (beta-lactam) provides appropriate dual coverage against Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which is the most common causative pathogen, particularly in patients with diabetes. Treatment lasts at least two weeks, with adjustments based on culture sensitivities when available.

C) INCORRECT:

Monotherapy with cefepime does not provide adequate coverage for malignant otitis externa.

D) INCORRECT:

This combination lacks adequate antipseudomonal coverage. Vancomycin primarily covers gram-positive organisms, and malignant otitis externa requires dual antipseudomonal agents from different antibiotic classes.

E) INCORRECT:

While piperacillin-tazobactam provides antipseudomonal coverage, vancomycin primarily targets gram-positive organisms and lacks significant activity against Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Malignant otitis externa requires dual antipseudomonal coverage from different antibiotic classes.

questions.text: An 82-year-old man presents with a 3-week history of severe left ear pain and discharge. The pain is worse at night and has not responded to topical antibiotic drops. He also reports increased thirst and fatigue over the past month. He has a history of hypertension. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F). Physical examination shows an edematous external auditory canal with a friable polypoid lesion on the floor at the osseocartilaginous junction. There is mild weakness noted with facial expression on the left. Which of the following laboratory findings is most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Elevated creatinine, indicating renal dysfunction, could be present in this patient due to his age, hypertension, and likely undiagnosed diabetes mellitus (diabetic nephropathy). However, while a possible comorbidity, it is not central to the pathophysiology of malignant otitis externa.

B) CORRECT:

The single most important predisposing factor for malignant otitis externa is poorly controlled diabetes mellitus, which is present in over 90% of cases. This patient's symptoms of polydipsia and fatigue strongly suggest underlying hyperglycemia. A hemoglobin A1c of 9.8% reflects an average blood glucose of approximately 235 mg/dL over the past 2–3 months, confirming chronic, severe hyperglycemia. This state impairs neutrophil function and creates a favorable environment for this aggressive infection. The presence of granulation tissue and facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) palsy indicates disease extension beyond the ear canal.

C) INCORRECT:

While the finding of mild hyponatremia would be consistent with this patient's underlying metabolic state, it is a secondary effect. The primary laboratory abnormality driving this patient's susceptibility to infection is something else.

D) INCORRECT:

An erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) of 25 mm/hr is only mildly elevated for an 82-year-old man. Necrotizing otitis externa is a form of osteomyelitis, which is a significant inflammatory process. Therefore, a markedly elevated ESR, often greater than 50–100 mm/hr, would be expected. This value is too low to be consistent with the severity of the suspected diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

A high absolute neutrophil count (neutrophilic leukocytosis) is an expected finding in a severe bacterial infection like malignant otitis externa. However, the degree of leukocytosis can be variable, and some older adults or immunocompromised patients may not mount a robust WBC response. Although plausible, it is a nonspecific marker of infection.
questions.hint: Severe, unremitting otalgia, granulation tissue at the osseocartilaginous junction, and a cranial nerve palsy in an older adult are highly suggestive of malignant (necrotizing) otitis externa, a condition strongly associated with a particular metabolic disorder.
